#Text=How did you approach putting together such a large-scale study ?
#Text=NG
#Text=: This study started in 1982 , long before my joining the lab in March of 2016 .
#Text=Dr. Dee Boersma began this study as a response to a Japanese company 's interest in harvesting penguins for their skin , meat , and oil .
#Text=Although the project has evolved over time , Dr. Boersma had the foresight to start banding chicks in 1983 and to set up a standard protocol that we follow each year .
#Text=Since then , over 44,000 chicks have been banded at Punta Tombo .
#Text=We ’ve been able to follow some individuals for 30+ years , collecting detailed information on things like how often they breed and how many mates they 've had .
#Text=( (
#Text=WN
#Text=) )
#Text=How much time did you end up spending in Argentina ?
#Text=What was it like at the breeding site ?
#Text=The two males continue their battle over the female .
#Text=Image : Natasha Gownaris .
#Text=NG
#Text=: Members of the Boersma lab and volunteers spend approximately six months each year at Punta Tombo .
#Text=I was fortunate enough to spend nearly four months at the colony between 2015 and 2017 .
#Text=It 's an incredible , otherworldly place .
#Text=Magellanic penguins nest in burrows or bushes , and some areas of the colony are so dense with burrows that you feel like you 're on a different planet .
#Text=The colony has declined by over 40 % since the study started ... so I ca n't even imagine what it was like in the 1980s .
#Text=My favorite time of the day is around 8PM , when ( hopefully fat ) penguins are returning to the colony en masse after a foraging trip .

#Text=They are also most vocal in the morning and evening , making their characteristic braying sound — the related African penguin earned the name " jackass penguin " because they sound a bit like donkeys .
#Text=The colony is also full of other beautiful and interesting creatures , including a llama-like species called the guanaco and an ostrich -like species called the rhea .
#Text=I was fortunate enough to spend nearly four months at the colony between 2015 and 2017 .
#Text=It 's an incredible , otherworldly place .
#Text=— Natasha Gownaris
#Text=( (
#Text=WN
#Text=) )
#Text=Do you have any theories on why more female juveniles die at sea ? You mention starvation ; what might be the causes of that , and are there other possible explanations you can think of ?
#Text=NG
#Text=: We are not yet certain why females are more likely to die , but we think it must be related to their smaller body size .
#Text=Because the mortality is most uneven in juveniles , higher mortality does n’t seem to be related to greater costs of breeding for females than for males .
#Text=Female
#Text=Magellanic penguins are about 17 % lighter than males and have smaller bills .

#Text=We think that , because of this size difference , females have a lower storage capacity , ca n't dive as deep , and ca n't take as wide a range of prey as males — all disadvantages when faced with limited and unpredictable food resources .
#Text=These disadvantages hit juvenile females even harder , as juveniles are still learning how to forage and often travel further than adults do in the non-breeding season .

#Text=Counts of carcasses in the species ' migration range support starvation as the main cause of female-biased mortality ; while oiled carcasses have a sex ratio of 1:1 , females outnumber males in carcasses of starved birds .
#Text=The only other possibility is that females are moving to other colonies at higher rates than are males , but this species is known to almost always return to its natal colony to breed .
